questions.text: The following given statements are true about spontaneous pneumothorax, except:

options.label: A
options.text: It has to be distinguished from the bullae or air cyst within the lung

options.label: B
options.text: There is rupture of the visceral pleura with no external trauma

options.label: C
options.text: There is no underlying lung condition present in spontaneous pneumothorax

options.label: D
options.text: It is does not have a valve like breech in the pleura

questions.correct_answer: C. There is no underlying lung condition present in spontaneous pneumothorax
questions.explanation:
Solution:

There is no underlying lung condition present in spontaneous pneumothorax Pneumothorax is the presence of air outside the lung , within the pleural space . it must be distinguished from bullae or air cysts within the lung. Bullae can coexist with pneumothorax as they can be the cause of air leak. In spontaneous pneumothorax visceral pleura ruptures without external trauma which is called primary SP and with underlying lung cause is called secondary SP.

Highyeild:

Risk factors of primary spontaneous pneumothorax Smoking Male sex Marfan syndrome Family history

questions.text: A 28 years old male was brought to the emergency with sudden onset of sharp chest pain with sweating and breathlessness. It started after an inconsolable cough which leads to increased severity leading to pain. On asking the patient had no such past history with no underlying disorders, but consumes alcohol occasionally. From the given scenario what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pneumothorax From the given scenario the patient is in his late 20s who had a sudden onset cough which might have led to spontaneous pneumothorax primary origin as gave no history of any underlying lung disorder. There is a strong association of pain and breathing, and in an attempt to breathe shallowly the patient experiences breathlessness.

Highyeild:

Risk factors of primary spontaneous pneumothorax Smoking Male sex Marfan syndrome Family history

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Cannot be the answer as the patient gives history of cough and then breathlessness and also the pain is usually throbbing in nature, there are no underlying disease present and patient is stable. Option: B. Cannot be the answer as in panic attack there is history of sudden fear and difficulty in breathing, on trying to take deep breathes there is relief and does not progress to further pain in the chest. The patient most of the time is aware of such conditions. Option: C. The pain is not sharp rather it is more of dull or pulled/ overworked in musculoskeletal.

questions.text: 58 years old male was diagnosed with spontaneous pneumothorax, which of the following statement is true if it’s a secondary spontaneous pneumothorax ?

options.label: A
options.text: Valve like opening is present in visceral pleura

options.label: B
options.text: The underlying cause is always a non- pulmonary condition

options.label: C
options.text: With increasing severity, more pain , more breathlessness

options.label: D
options.text: It is a self limiting condition in stable patients

questions.correct_answer: D. It is a self limiting condition in stable patients
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is a self limiting condition in stable patients In spontaneous pneumothorax unless the person is hypoxic it is not an emergency, but preparation for chest tube should be there.

Highyeild:

Secondary Spontaneous Pneumothorax Secondary Spontaneous Pneumothorax is a type of pneumothorax that occurs in individuals with underlying lung diseases such as COPD, asthma, or cystic fibrosis. Clinical features are typically more severe and tend to occur in older patients. Patients commonly present with sharp pleuritic pain and breathlessness . The treatment of choice is insertion of an intercostal drain (ICD).

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Valve is present in tension pneumothorax Option: B. The underlying condition are pulmonary conditions like tuberculosis, degenerative or lung cavitating diseases. Option: C. The severity of pain decreases in severe cases but breathlessness increases as in this case visceral pleura do not rub against the parietal pleura

questions.text: Which of the following are the Indications for surgical intervention for pneumothorax is false?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Unilateral spontaneous pneumothorax Summary box 55.1 Indications for surgical intervention for pneumothorax include: • Second ipsilateral pneumothorax • First contralateral pneumothorax • Bilateral spontaneous pneumothorax • Pneumothorax fails to settle despite chest drainage • Spontaneous haemothorax: professions at risk (e.g. pilots, divers) • Pregnancy

questions.text: The safest site for insertion of a drain is the triangle with following boundaries, which is true:

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior border of the latissimus dorsi muscle

options.label: B
options.text: Below and lateral to the pectoralis minor muscle

options.label: D
options.text: The level of the nipple- apex of the triangle

questions.correct_answer: D. The level of the nipple- apex of the triangle
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The level of the nipple- apex of the triangle Boundaries of the triangle are: Anterior to the mid – axillary line Above the level of the nipple Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle Site for the triangle of safety for the insertion of a drain.

Highyeild:

The safest site for drain insertion is in a triangle located: Anterior to the mid-axillary line Above the nipple level Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle Suction on a pleural tube • Be aware! Inserting the drain, and not the suction, is the life- saving manoeuvre • If the lung is reluctant to expand, the suction deviates the mediastinum • If the lung is fragile, it may worsen an air leak

Extraedge:

Applying suction or clamping the drain is not recommended. Clamping the drain during transport can be dangerous if forgotten. There are small risks of disconnection and siphoning if the drain is left unclamped. It is best to avoid clamping and use alternative methods to prevent disconnection and siphoning.

questions.text: True statement regarding the underwater seal:

options.label: A
options.text: The drain tube end should be below the water level

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to prevent entry of outside air

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above The under water seal helps in expelling air and not let the outside air enter the lung. In this the chest drain is placed in an underwater seal with the tube end at least 2 inches below the water level. During expiration bubbling occurs which helps us to know the tube is rightly placed and while inspiration the water rises in the tube not allowing the outside air to enter.

Highyeild:

Intercostal tube with underwater seal is important for chest disease management, but pleura and chest drain management can be difficult. Safest drain insertion site is in the triangle: Anterior to mid-axillary line Above nipple level Below and lateral to pectoralis major muscle.

Extraedge:

Applying suction or clamping the drain is not recommended. Clamping the drain during transport can be dangerous if forgotten. There are small risks of disconnection and siphoning if the drain is left unclamped. It is best to avoid clamping and use alternative methods to prevent disconnection and siphoning.

questions.text: In surgical management of pneumothorax , stripping of parietal pleura from the chest wall is done , which of the following statements are true? It is done for pleural adhesion It helps to obliterate and contain the subsequent leak Can be performed by VATS Another procedure of pleural adhesion called as chemical pleurodesis Rigid bronchoscope is used Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3 & 4 Surgical management for pneumothorax can be performed by VATS and open procedure. It deals with leak from the lung , obliterate blebs and pleura and adhesion of visceral and parietal pleura to contain the subsequent leak. Pleural adhesion can be obtained by the following procedure : Pleurectomy – systemically stripping the parietal pleura from the chest wall Pleural adhesion – a source is used to scrape off the slick surface of the parietal pleura Chemical pleurodesis – usually talc is used and is insufflated the chest cavity

Highyeild:

Surgery for pneumothorax can be done via video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) or an open procedure (thoracotomy) for three reasons: To deal with any lung leaks. To find and get rid of blebs and bullae. To make the visceral pleura stick to the parietal pleura to prevent future leaks and total lung collapse.

Extraedge:

There are three ways to achieve pleural adhesion: Pleurectomy: systematically stripping the parietal pleura from the chest wall. Pleural abrasion: using a scourer to scrape off the slick surface of the parietal pleura. Chemical pleurodesis: typically using talc, which is insufflated into the chest cavity.

questions.text: Pleural effusion occurs when there is disturbance in pleural fluid balance , which of the following is not the most common reason ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased intravascular oncotic pressure Reduced intravascular oncotic pressure Causes of pleural effusion • Elevated pulmonary capillary pressure. If left atrial pres- sure rises, the pulmonary capillary pressure must rise with it, as a result of either impaired cardiac performance or an overloaded circulation. • Reduced intravascular oncotic pressure. If the plasma proteins fall because of renal or hepatic disease or malnu- trition, the absorption mechanism fails. • Accumulation of pleural protein due to obstruction of the mediastinal lymphatics secondary to lymphoma or cancers that invade the lymphatic system. • Excessive permeability of the capillaries to fluid and pro- tein as in inflammatory diseases, particularly the collagen vascular diseases. Of particular importance to the surgeon is the effusion associated with pleural infection (empy- ema) and malignant effusions.

Highyeild:

Pleural effusions are divided into exudates and transudates based on protein content (more or less than 30 g/L), and further characterized by glucose content, pH, and lactate dehydrogenase content. The most common ways in which the pleural fluid balance is disturbed are: Malignant pleural effusion, which is a common complication of cancer. This may be due to lung cancer, pleural involvement with primary or secondary malignancy, or mediastinal lymphatic involvement.

Extraedge:

Pleural biopsy can be obtained through various techniques. VATS is the most common method for pleural biopsy.

questions.text: A 54 year old female presented with sharp chest pain in her right side, she had a fever on- off for a month, coughing with anticipation. She is a known patient of diabetes with ongoing treatment. The doctor thoroughly examined her and carried out a few investigations. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Empyema From the given image and history the female is diagnosed with pleural empyema. The image shows the obliteration of the costo- diaphragmatic angle which is radio- opaque shadow.

Highyeild:

Empyema is the end stage of pleural infection from any cause. It usually occurs as a complication of pneumonia or a lung abscess, but can also result from any thoracic operation. Empyema can develop if a traumatic haemothorax becomes infected, or during management of pneumothorax or pleural effusions. Empyema may be associated with pus under the diaphragm. The pathological diagnosis of empyema requires the presence of thick pus with a thick cortex of fibrin and coagulum over the lung.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Pneumothorax – chest x-ray will be radiolucent Option: C. Lung abscess will present with radiopaque shadow in the lung parenchyma Option: D. Hemo-pneumothorax – there is presence of air- fluid level in the chest.

questions.text: A 48 years old male presented with chest pain, fever, cough and fatigue. On examination the doctor suspected it to be pleural effusion but was not responding to antibiotics. Thus, to confirm the diagnosis biopsy was done, which of the following methods is most commonly used ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

VATS biopsy Pleural biopsy can be obtained by a range of techniques, with VATS being the most common.

Highyeild:

The direct-vision thoracoscope was limited to biopsies. Video-assisted thoracoscopy allows hands-free use of the thoracoscope. The surgeon can manipulate instruments with both hands. The number of ports needed varies by surgery complexity. Patients are usually positioned with the diseased side up and have a double-lumen ETT for single-lung ventilation. Large incision is avoided, resulting in less postoperative pain and a more rapid recovery.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Cytological examination: Cytological examination involves collecting cells from the pleural fluid and examining them under a microscope to look for any abnormal cells that may indicate a malignant condition. This method is less invasive than biopsy and can be done through a simple needle aspiration, but it may not always provide a definitive diagnosis. Option C. CT-guided needle biopsy: CT-guided needle biopsy involves using imaging guidance to direct a biopsy needle into the pleural space to obtain a tissue sample for biopsy. This method is less invasive than VATS biopsy and can be done on an outpatient basis, but it may not always provide a large enough sample for a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with lung abscess but left it untreated, after a few months he presents with similar complaints but with increased severity, doctor suspects it to be empyema, which of the following are true regarding empyema except?

options.label: A
options.text: Thick pus, thick cortex of fibrin and coagulum present over the lung

options.label: B
options.text: Decortication when lung fail to re- expand after drainage of the pus

options.label: C
options.text: VATS drainage is done along with pleural biopsy and pleurodesis

options.label: D
options.text: In fibrinopurulent phase, drainage of pus is must

questions.correct_answer: B. Decortication when lung fail to re- expand after drainage of the pus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decortication when lung fail to re- expand after drainage of the pus Decortication is done when the lung fails to re – expand after surgical debridement followed by antibiotics and physiotherapy.

Highyeild:

Empyema is the end stage of pleural infection from any cause. It usually occurs as a complication of pneumonia or a lung abscess, but can also result from any thoracic operation. Empyema can develop if a traumatic haemothorax becomes infected, or during management of pneumothorax or pleural effusions. Empyema may be associated with pus under the diaphragm. The pathological diagnosis of empyema requires the presence of thick pus with a thick cortex of fibrin and coagulum over the lung.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- A, C, D: are correct as in empyema the pus is thick with thick cortex of fibrin and coagulum present. There are three phases of empyema – Exudative phase – antibiotics are used to treat Fibrinopurulent phase – antibiotics only do not suffice so draining of pus is important Organizing phase – lung is trapped by the thick cortex which is necessary to be peeled off. by a surgical approach. Also, as in when the VATS drainage is done, pleural biopsy and pleurodesis is taken place along with it.

questions.text: Which of these is true about the thoracic outlet syndrome from the following, except?

options.label: B
options.text: More common in males than females

options.label: C
options.text: Boundaries are collar bone and first rib

questions.correct_answer: B. More common in males than females
questions.explanation:
Solution:

More common in males than females Thoracic outlet syndrome occurs in the space where the boundaries are formed by the collar bone and the first rib Contents are the scalene muscles , subclavian artery and vein, brachial plexus It occurs when the pressure inside the space increases , muscle hypertrophy usually does that. In whiplash injury the structures in the neck are hurt leading to TOS .

Highyeild:

Fibrous band from C7 to 1st thoracic rib Can be asymptomatic May cause symptoms due to subclavian artery and brachial plexus Compression of lower trunk of plexus (T1) can lead to interossei wasting and altered sensation in T1 area

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Muscle hypertrophy: Thoracic outlet syndrome can occur due to compression of neurovascular structures in the thoracic outlet. This can be caused by various factors, including muscle hypertrophy, which can lead to compression of the nerves and blood vessels passing through the thoracic outlet. Option: C. Boundaries are collar bone and first rib: The thoracic outlet is a narrow passageway located between the collarbone (clavicle) and the first rib, through which various nerves and blood vessels pass to reach the arm. Option: D. Whiplash injury: Whiplash injury is not typically associated with the development of thoracic outlet syndrome. However, traumatic injury to the neck or shoulder region can cause damage to the nerves or blood vessels in the thoracic outlet, leading to the development of thoracic outlet syndrome.

Extraedge:

Compression of subclavian artery can cause poststenotic dilatation, thrombus, and embolus Diagnosis, assessment, and surgery are complex and best left to specialists with interest in this issue.

questions.text: A 28 years old female presented to the OPD for pain and tingling over the posterior aspect of my forearm. She experiences this pain usually during evening hours which progresses to the shoulder, she mentioned it to be numbing pain and loss of control over grip with heaviness in fingers. Which of the following is the most accurate diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neurogenic TOS From the given history of the patient- she is suffering from neurogenic thoracic outlet syndrome. This is when the brachial plexus gets compressed in the space between the collar bone and the first rib. The most common nerve to be affected is T1 . Similar presentation of tingling and numbness is present in the forearm and fingers in tennis elbow on the extensor aspect and pain and tingling sensation at the thumb, index and middle finger with flattening of the nerve eminence in carpal tunnel syndrome.

Highyeild:

Thoracic outlet syndrome diagnosed clinically Based on reproducibility of symptoms from nerve and blood vessel compression Confirmed with mechanical provocative maneuvers (Adson’s test, costoclavicular test, Hyperabduction test, Roos Arm Claudication test) CT scan, MRI, Angiography, and X-ray used to rule out other conditions and establish associated diagnosis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Tennis elbow Lateral epicondyle = origin of forearm extensors Palpate for tenderness, usually 5-10 mm distal to the epicondyle near extensor carpi radialis brevis muscle Wrist extension against resistance with extended elbow can provoke symptoms. Option: B. Carpal tunnel syndrome Carpal tunnel syndrome mostly has no known cause (idiopathic). It can be linked to several conditions such as diabetes and thyroid disorders. Alcoholism, amyloidosis, and inflammatory arthritis are also associated with carpal tunnel syndrome. Pregnancy and obesity can also increase the risk of developing carpal tunnel syndrome. Option: C. Thoracic outlet syndrome Thoracic outlet syndrome occurs in the space where the boundaries are formed by the collar bone and the first rib Contents are the scalene muscles , subclavian artery and vein, brachial plexus It occurs when the pressure inside the space increases , muscle hypertrophy usually does that. In whiplash injury the structures in the neck are hurt leading to TOS .

Extraedge:

For thoracic outlet syndrome : Surgical intervention may be indicated if conservative management fails or there is a progression of sensory or motor symptoms. Surgical intervention may also be indicated in cases of excessively prolonged ulnar or median nerve conduction velocities, narrowing or occlusion of the subclavian artery thrombosis of the axillary or subclavian vein. The operation for TOS involves complete removal of the first rib, with division of scalenus anterior and medius Large aneurysms or thrombosis of the subclavian artery may require graft reconstruction , while subclavian vein thrombosis may require thrombolytic and anticoagulant therapy and simultaneous surgical decompression.

questions.text: Masaoka staging system is used in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thymoma Masaoka thymoma staging system : Macroscopically completely encapsulated, microscopically no capsular invasion Macroscopic invasion into surrounding fatty tissue or mediastinal pleura, microscopic invasion into the capsule. Macroscopic invasion into neighboring organs (pericardium, great vessels, lungs) Pleural or pericardial dissemination Lymphogenous or haematogenous metastasis

Highyeild:

Thymoma is a common mediastinal tumor derived from the thymus gland. Thymomas can range from benign to aggressively invasive. They are often associated with myasthenia gravis. Capsular invasion is the only reliable indicator of malignancy. Complete thymectomy is the best way to diagnose and treat thymoma. CT scan of the chest revealing a large necrotic mass in the left anterior mediastinum (thymoma) and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. SVC syndrome is a group of symptoms that occur when the superior vena cava, a large vein that carries blood from the head and arms back to the heart, becomes partially or fully blocked. It is most commonly caused by lung cancer or lymphoma pressing on the vein. Option: B. Carcinoma of lung is a malignant tumor that starts in the cells of the lung tissue. It is one of the most common types of cancer and is usually staged using the TNM system. Option: C. Lymphoma is a type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, which is part of the body's immune system. It is divided into two main types: Hodgkin lymphoma and non-Hodgkin lymphoma. The staging of lymphoma is usually done using the Ann Arbor staging system.

Extraedge:

For large tumors or suspected tumor invasion, median sternotomy is performed. Less invasive approaches can be considered for small tumors or when thymus is being excised as a treatment, including VATS approach or transcervical approach.

questions.text: Extra gonadal germ cell tumor is most commonly found in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterior mediastinum Germ cell tumor: The anterior mediastinum is the most common site of extragonadal germ cell tumors. They account for 13% of all mediastinal masses and cysts and contain elements from all three cell types (mesoderm, endoderm and ectoderm). They tend to present in young adults and 75% are benign and cystic, although they may cause compression of neighboring structures; hence, dermoid cysts are best excised. Malignancy is suspected if elevated levels of serum alpha-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin and carcinoembryonic antigen are detected. After initial treatment with chemotherapy, a patient with tumor marker normalization and a persistent mass on CT may be considered for surgical resection. If tumor markers fail to normalize, further chemotherapy is usually offered.

Highyeild:

Anterior mediastinum: common site of extragonadal germ cell tumors Accounts for 13% of all mediastinal masses and cysts Contains elements from all three cell types (mesoderm, endoderm, and ectoderm) Presents in young adults; 75% are benign and cystic Dermoid cysts should be excised if they cause compression of neighboring structures Malignancy suspected if elevated levels of serum alpha-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin, and carcinoembryonic antigen detected

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Middle mediastinum: Germ cell tumors in the middle mediastinum are less common than those in the anterior mediastinum. This area contains the heart and pericardium, and tumors in this location may cause symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, and palpitations. Option: C. Posterior mediastinum: Germ cell tumors in the posterior mediastinum are even less common than those in the middle mediastinum. This area contains the esophagus, aorta, and vertebral column, and tumors in this location may cause symptoms such as back pain, difficulty swallowing, and numbness or weakness in the legs. Option: D. Superior mediastinum: Germ cell tumors in the superior mediastinum are the least common of all mediastinal germ cell tumors. This area contains the trachea, esophagus, thymus, and great vessels, and tumors in this location may cause symptoms such as cough, hoarseness, and swelling of the face and neck.

Extraedge:

Initial treatment with chemotherapy; surgical resection may be considered for persistent mass on CT Further chemotherapy is offered if tumor markers fail to normalize.

questions.text: A 45 year old female presented with sharp pleuritic chest pain with difficulty in respiration. On auscultating the patient, breath sounds are decreased on the left side, hyperresonant on percussion and chest X-ray showed tracheal shift to opposite side. Which of the following modality of treatment is appropriate for the above condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Surgery for pneumothorax can be performed by video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery ( VATS ) or as an open procedure ( thoracotomy ). The object of the exercise is threefold: to deal with any leaks from the lung; to search for and obliterate any blebs and bullae; to make the visceral pleura adherent to the parietal pleura so that any subsequent leaks are contained and the lung cannot completely collapse. Pleural adhesion is achieved in one of three ways: Pleurectomy : systematically stripping the parietal pleura from the chest wall. Pleural abrasion : a scourer is used to scrape off the slick surface of the parietal pleura. Chemical pleurodesis : usually talc is used and is insufflated into the chest cavity.

Highyeild:

Surgery for pneumothorax can be done in two ways: Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) Open procedure (thoracotomy) The goals of the surgery are: To fix lung leaks To remove blebs and bullae To make sure that the visceral pleura sticks to the parietal pleura so that future leaks are contained and the lung doesn't collapse entirely. There are three ways to achieve pleural adhesion: Pleurectomy: removing the parietal pleura from the chest wall systematically Pleural abrasion: using a scourer to scrape the slick surface of the parietal pleura Chemical pleurodesis: talc is typically used and insufflated into the chest cavity.

Extraedge:

VATS doesn't create a working space by adding an insufflating gas It creates a working space by removing air from the ipsilateral lung parenchyma This causes the collapse of the ipsilateral lung.
